TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract sealed beforefieldinit Stylus extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides access to general information about a tablet pen.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to record the coordinates of the stylus, even if the stylus leaves the bounds of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox>. This example assumes that there is a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox> called `textBox1`, and that the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusDown>, <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusUp>, and <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusMove> events are connected to event handlers.
[!code-csharp[StylusSamples#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#1)] [!code-vb[StylusSamples#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static bool Capture (System.Windows.IInputElement element);
.method public static hidebysig bool Capture(class System.Windows.IInputElement element) cil managed

Docs.param: The element to capture the stylus to.
Docs.summary: Captures the stylus to the specified element.
Docs.returns: if the stylus is captured to ; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.Capture%28System.Windows.IInputElement%29> method to ensure that `element` receives stylus events even when the cursor goes out of the elements' bounds. To release the stylus, call <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.Capture%28System.Windows.IInputElement%2CSystem.Windows.Input.CaptureMode%29> with the <xref:System.Windows.Input.CaptureMode> set to <xref:System.Windows.Input.CaptureMode.None>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.Capture%28System.Windows.IInputElement%29> method returns `false` if `element` is not visible or enabled.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to record the coordinates of the stylus, even if the stylus leaves the bounds of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox>. This example assumes there is a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox> called `textBox1`, and that the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusDown>, <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusUp>, and <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusMove> events are connected to event handlers.
[!code-csharp[StylusSamples#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#1)] [!code-vb[StylusSamples#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static bool Capture (System.Windows.IInputElement element, System.Windows.Input.CaptureMode captureMode);
.method public static hidebysig bool Capture(class System.Windows.IInputElement element, valuetype System.Windows.Input.CaptureMode captureMode) cil managed

Docs.param: The element to capture the stylus to.
One of the values.
Docs.summary: Captures the stylus to the specified element.
Docs.returns: if the stylus is captured to ; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.Capture%28System.Windows.IInputElement%2CSystem.Windows.Input.CaptureMode%29> method to ensure that `element` receives stylus events even when the cursor goes out of the elements' bounds. To release the stylus, call <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.Capture%28System.Windows.IInputElement%2CSystem.Windows.Input.CaptureMode%29> with the <xref:System.Windows.Input.CaptureMode> set to <xref:System.Windows.Input.CaptureMode.None>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.Capture%28System.Windows.IInputElement%2CSystem.Windows.Input.CaptureMode%29> method returns `false` if `element` is not visible or enabled.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to record the coordinates of the stylus, even if the stylus leaves the bounds of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox>. This example assumes that there is a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox> called `textBox1`, and that the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusDown>, <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusUp>, and <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusMove> events are connected to the event handlers.
[!code-csharp[StylusSamples#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#1)] [!code-vb[StylusSamples#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Windows.IInputElement Captured { get; }
.property class System.Windows.IInputElement Captured

Docs.summary: Gets the element to which the stylus is bound.
Docs.value: The to which the stylus is bound.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to ensure that the stylus is not captured when the user touches the stylus to the digitizer. This example assumes that the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.PreviewStylusDown> event is connected to the event handler.
[!code-csharp[StylusSamples#5](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#5)] [!code-vb[StylusSamples#5](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#5)]

.property class System.Windows.Input.StylusDevice CurrentStylusDevice

Docs.summary: Gets the stylus that represents the stylus currently in use.
Docs.value: The that represents the stylus currently in use.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to erase the text that is selected with an inverted stylus. This example assumes that there is a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox> called `textBox1` and that the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusUpEvent> event is connected to the event handler.
[!code-csharp[StylusSamples#8](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#8)] [!code-vb[StylusSamples#8](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#8)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Windows.IInputElement DirectlyOver { get; }
.property class System.Windows.IInputElement DirectlyOver

Docs.summary: Gets the element that is directly beneath the stylus.
Docs.value: The that is directly beneath the stylus.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to determine which element the stylus is positioned over. This example assumes that there is a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox> called `textBox1` and that the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.StylusInAirMove> event is connected to the event handler.
[!code-csharp[StylusSamples#3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#3)] [!code-vb[StylusSamples#3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#3)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static bool GetIsFlicksEnabled (System.Windows.DependencyObject element);
.method public static hidebysig bool GetIsFlicksEnabled(class System.Windows.DependencyObject element) cil managed

Docs.param: A or on which to determine whether flicks are enabled.
Docs.summary: Gets the value of the attached property on the specified element.
Docs.returns: if the specified element has flicks enabled; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks In Windows Vista, a flick, one of the possible system gestures, is a short, quick, straight stroke that can be mapped to a navigation or shortcut command. By default, flicks are disabled on the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvas>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkPresenter>, and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.ScrollBar>. Flicks are enabled on all other controls.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to determine whether flicks are enabled on a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Canvas>.
[!code-csharp[GestureSample#6](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/GestureSample/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#6)] [!code-vb[GestureSample#6](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/GestureSample/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#6)]

.method public static hidebysig bool GetIsPressAndHoldEnabled(class System.Windows.DependencyObject element) cil managed

Docs.param: A or on which to determine whether press and hold is enabled.
Docs.summary: Gets the value of the attached property on the specified element.
Docs.returns: if the specified element has press and hold enabled; otherwise, ;

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to enable press and hold on a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Slider>. This example assumes that there is a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Slider> called `horizontalSlider1`.
[!code-csharp[StylusSamples#9](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#9)] [!code-vb[StylusSamples#9](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#9)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static bool GetIsTapFeedbackEnabled (System.Windows.DependencyObject element);
.method public static hidebysig bool GetIsTapFeedbackEnabled(class System.Windows.DependencyObject element) cil managed

Docs.param: A or on which to determine whether tap feedback enabled.
Docs.summary: Gets the value of the attached property on the specified element.
Docs.returns: if the specified element has tap feedback enabled; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks In Windows Vista, a short animation occurs when the user taps the control. By default, tap feedback is disabled on the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvas>. It is enabled on all other controls.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to determine whether tap feedback is enabled on a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Canvas>.
[!code-csharp[GestureSample#5](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/GestureSample/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#5)] [!code-vb[GestureSample#5](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/GestureSample/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#5)]

remarks.format:

MemberSignature.Value: public static void SetIsFlicksEnabled (System.Windows.DependencyObject element, bool enabled);
.method public static hidebysig void SetIsFlicksEnabled(class System.Windows.DependencyObject element, bool enabled) cil managed

Docs.param: The or on which to enable flicks.
to enable flicks; to disable flicks.
Docs.summary: Gets the value of the attached property on the specified element.

remarks.format:
## Remarks In Windows Vista, a flick, one of the possible system gestures, is a short, quick, straight stroke that can be mapped to a navigation or shortcut command. By default, flicks are disabled on the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvas>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkPresenter>, and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.ScrollBar>. Flicks are enabled on all other controls.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to disable flicks on a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Canvas>.
[!code-csharp[GestureSample#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/GestureSample/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#2)] [!code-vb[GestureSample#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/GestureSample/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#2)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static void SetIsPressAndHoldEnabled (System.Windows.DependencyObject element, bool enabled);
.method public static hidebysig void SetIsPressAndHoldEnabled(class System.Windows.DependencyObject element, bool enabled) cil managed

Docs.param: The or on which to enable press and hold.
to enable press and hold; to disable press and hold.
Docs.summary: Sets the value of the attached property on the specified element.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Press and hold maps to the right-click on a mouse. In Windows Vista, you can disable this behavior on elements if you foresee a situation where the user might hold the tablet pen down without intending to simulate a right-click.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to enable press and hold on a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Slider>. This example assumes that there is a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Slider> called `horizontalSlider1`.
[!code-csharp[StylusSamples#9](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#9)] [!code-vb[StylusSamples#9](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#9)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static void SetIsTapFeedbackEnabled (System.Windows.DependencyObject element, bool enabled);
.method public static hidebysig void SetIsTapFeedbackEnabled(class System.Windows.DependencyObject element, bool enabled) cil managed

Docs.param: The or on which to enable tap feedback.
to enable tap feedback; to disable tap feedback.
Docs.summary: Sets the value of the attached property on the specified element.

remarks.format:
## Remarks In Windows Vista, a short animation occurs when the user taps the control. By default, tap feedback is disabled on the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvas>. It is enabled on all other controls.
## Examples The following example disables tap feedback on a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Canvas>.
[!code-csharp[GestureSample#4](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/GestureSample/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#4)] [!code-vb[GestureSample#4](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/GestureSample/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#4)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static void SetIsTouchFeedbackEnabled (System.Windows.DependencyObject element, bool enabled);
.method public static hidebysig void SetIsTouchFeedbackEnabled(class System.Windows.DependencyObject element, bool enabled) cil managed

Docs.param: The or on which to enable tap feedback.
to enable touch input feedback; to disable touch input feedback.
Docs.summary: Sets the value of the attached property on the specified element.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example enables touch feedback on an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvas>.
[!code-csharp[GestureSample#8](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/GestureSample/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#8)] [!code-vb[GestureSample#8](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/GestureSample/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#8)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static void Synchronize ();
.method public static hidebysig void Synchronize() cil managed

Docs.summary: Synchronizes the cursor and the user interface.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Applications may need to determine the element on which the cursor is located. If the application uses animation, the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.DirectlyOver%2A> method might return an element that has moved out from under the cursor. Call <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.Synchronize%2A> to be sure that <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.DirectlyOver%2A> returns the proper element.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to get the element that is under the cursor. Calling <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.Synchronize%2A> ensures that <xref:System.Windows.Input.Stylus.DirectlyOver%2A> returns the correct element.
[!code-csharp[StylusSamples#24](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/CSharp/Window2.xaml.cs#24)] [!code-vb[StylusSamples#24](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/VisualBasic/Window2.xaml.vb#24)] [!code-csharp[StylusSamples#25](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/CSharp/Window2.xaml.cs#25)] [!code-vb[StylusSamples#25](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/StylusSamples/VisualBasic/Window2.xaml.vb#25)]
